             1196          Section 21. Section 62A-4a-402 is amended to read:
             1197           62A-4a-402. Definitions.
             1198          As used in this part:
             1199          (1) "A person responsible for a child's care" means the child's parent, guardian, or other
             1200      person responsible for the child's care, whether in:
             1201          (a) the same home as the child[,];
             1202          (b) a relative's home[,];
             1203          (c) a group, family, or center day care facility[,];
             1204          (d) a foster care home[,]; or
             1205          (e) a residential institution.

             1206          (2) "Child" means a person under 18 years of age.
             1207          (3) "Child abuse" [or neglect" means causing harm or threatened harm to a child's
             1208      health or welfare.] has the same meaning as "abuse" defined in Section 62A-4a-101 .
             1209          (4) "Neglect" has the same meaning as defined in Section 62A-4a-101 .
             1210          [(4) "Harm or threatened harm" means damage or threatened damage to the physical or
             1211      emotional health and welfare of a child through neglect or abuse, and includes but is not
             1212      limited to:]
             1213          [(a) causing nonaccidental physical or mental injury;]
             1214          [(b) incest;]
             1215          [(c) sexual abuse;]
             1216          [(d) sexual exploitation;]
             1217          [(e) molestation; or]
             1218          [(f) repeated negligent treatment or maltreatment.]
             1219          (5) "Incest" means having sexual intercourse with a person whom the perpetrator
             1220      knows to be [his or her] the perpetrator's ancestor, descendant, brother, sister, uncle, aunt,
             1221      nephew, niece, or first cousin. The relationships referred to in this Subsection (5) include:
             1222          (a) blood relationships of the whole or half blood without regard to legitimacy[, and
             1223      include];
             1224          (b) relationships of parent and child by adoption[,]; and
             1225          (c) relationships of stepparent and stepchild while the marriage creating the
             1226      relationship of a stepparent and stepchild exists.
             1227          (6) "Molestation" means:
             1228          (a) touching the anus or any part of the genitals of a child or otherwise taking indecent
             1229      liberties with a child[,]; or
             1230          (b) causing a child to take indecent liberties with the perpetrator or another with the
             1231      intent to arouse or gratify the sexual desire of any person.
             1232          (7) "Sexual abuse" means acts or attempted acts of sexual intercourse, sodomy, or
             1233      molestation directed towards a child.
             1234          (8) (a) "Sexual exploitation of minors" means:
             1235          (i) knowingly employing, using, persuading, inducing, enticing or coercing any minor
             1236      to pose in the nude for the purpose of sexual arousal of any person or for profit[, or to engage];

             1237          (ii) engaging in any sexual or simulated sexual conduct for the purpose of
             1238      photographing, filming, recording, or displaying in any way the sexual or simulated sexual
             1239      conduct[, and].
             1240          (b) "Sexual exploitation of minors" includes displaying, distributing, possessing for the
             1241      purpose of distribution, or selling material depicting minors in the nude or engaging in sexual
             1242      or simulated sexual conduct.
             1243          (9) "Subject" or "subject of the report" means any person reported under this part,
             1244      including, but not limited to, a child, parent, guardian, or other person responsible for a child's
             1245      care.
             1246          Section 22. Section 62A-4a-403 is amended to read:
             1247           62A-4a-403. Reporting requirements.
             1248          (1) Except as provided in [Subsection] Subsections (2) through (4), when any person
             1249      including persons licensed under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act, or Title 58,
             1250      Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act, has [reason] probable cause to believe, and not merely

             1253      described in Subsection 62A-4a-116.1 (2), or who observes a child being subjected to

             1255      neglect, [he] that person shall immediately notify the nearest peace officer, law enforcement

             1263      priest, without the consent of the person making the confession, with regard to any confession

             1284      other than the child's usual primary care doctor or specialist;
             1285          (c) decline treatment on behalf of the child when the treatment poses a substantial risk
             1286      of serious harm to the child's immediate or future physical or mental health;
             1287          (d) obtain nontraditional treatment from a medical or mental health practitioner; or
             1288          (e) otherwise act in a manner consistent with what a reasonable parent or guardian
             1289      would do under similar circumstances.
             1290          Section 23. Section 62A-4a-409 is amended to read:

             1292      Preremoval interviews of children.

             1325          (9) With regard to any interview of a child prior to removal of that child from the
             1326      child's home:
             1327          (a) except as provided in Subsection (9)(b) or (c), the division shall [notify] inform a
             1328      parent of the child prior to the interview[;] of:
             1329          (i) the specific allegations concerning the child; and

             1330          (ii) the time and place of the interview;
             1331          (b) if a child's parent or stepparent, or a parent's paramour has been identified as the
             1332      alleged perpetrator, the division need not notify a parent of the child prior to an initial interview
             1333      with the child;
             1334          (c) if the perpetrator is unknown, or if the perpetrator's relationship to the child's family
             1335      is unknown, the division may conduct a minimal interview, not to exceed 15 minutes, with the
             1336      child prior to notification of the child's parent;
             1337          (d) in all cases described in Subsection (9)(b) or (c), a parent of the child shall be
             1338      notified as soon as practicable after the child has been interviewed, but in no case later than 24
             1339      hours after the interview has taken place;
             1340          (e) a child's parents shall be notified of the time and place of all subsequent interviews
             1341      with the child; and
             1342          (f) the child shall be allowed to have a support person of the child's choice present[.
             1343      That support person: (i) may include, but is not limited to,]:
             1344          (i) including a school teacher [or], administrator, guidance counselor, or child care
             1345      provider; and
             1346          (ii) [may not be] not including a person who is alleged to be, or potentially may be, the
             1347      perpetrator.
             1348          (10) In accordance with the procedures and requirements of Sections 62A-4a-202.1
             1349      through 62A-4a-202.3 , a division worker or child protection team member may take a child
             1350      into protective custody and deliver the child to a law enforcement officer, or place the child in
             1351      an emergency shelter facility approved by the juvenile court, at the earliest opportunity
             1352      subsequent to the child's removal from the child's original environment. Control and
             1353      jurisdiction over the child is determined by the provisions of Title 78, Chapter 3a, Juvenile
             1354      Court Act of 1996, and as otherwise provided by law.
             1355          (11) With regard to cases in which law enforcement has or is conducting an
             1356      investigation of alleged abuse or neglect of a child:
             1357          (a) the division shall coordinate with law enforcement to ensure that there is an
             1358      adequate safety plan to protect the child from further abuse or neglect; and
             1359          (b) the division is not required to duplicate an aspect of the investigation that, in the
             1360      division's determination, has been satisfactorily completed by law enforcement.

             1367          Section 25. Section 76-5-109 is amended to read:
             1368           76-5-109. Child abuse.
             1369          (1) As used in this section:
             1370          (a) "Child" means a human being who is under 18 years of age.
             1371          (b) "Child abuse" means any offense described in Subsection (2) or (3)[,] or in Section
             1372      76-5-109.1 [.], but does not include:
             1373          (i) unintentional incidents resulting from ordinary human error, including unintentional
             1374      accidents and unintentional injuries, unless the injury, accident, or other incident was caused
             1375      intentionally, knowingly, recklessly, or with criminal negligence, as defined in Section
             1376      76-2-103 ; and
             1377          (ii) reasonable parental discipline or management of a child with which a child may
             1378      disagree, including prohibiting the use of an automobile or other possession and the
             1379      withholding of other privileges, if the prohibiting or withholding does not constitute serious
             1380      physical abuse, serious neglect, sexual abuse or exploitation, or mental cruelty.
             1381          (c) "Mental cruelty" means conduct which:
             1382          (i) causes serious chronic anguish in a child; and
             1383          (ii) impairs the child's social and emotional functioning.
             1384          [(c)] (d) "Physical injury" means an injury to or health condition of a child which
             1385      [impairs] results in actual harm to the physical [condition] health of the child and is not a
             1386      serious physical injury, including:
             1387          (i) a bruise or other contusion of the skin;
             1388          (ii) a minor laceration or abrasion; and
             1389          (iii) failure to thrive or malnutrition[; or].
             1390          [(iv) any other condition which imperils the child's health or welfare and which is not a
             1391      serious physical injury as defined in Subsection (1)(d).]

             1392          [(d)] (e) "Serious physical injury" means any physical injury or set of injuries which
             1393      [seriously impairs the child's] results in serious harm to the physical health[, or which] of the
             1394      child, involves physical torture [or causes serious emotional harm to] of the child, or which
             1395      involves a substantial risk of death to the child, including:
             1396          (i) fracture of any bone or bones;
             1397          (ii) intracranial bleeding, swelling or contusion of the brain, whether caused by blows,
             1398      shaking, or causing the child's head to impact with an object or surface;
             1399          (iii) any burn, including burns inflicted by hot water, or those caused by placing a hot
             1400      object upon the skin or body of the child;
             1401          (iv) any injury caused by use of a dangerous weapon as defined in Section 76-1-601 ;
             1402          (v) any combination of two or more physical injuries inflicted by the same person,
             1403      either at the same time or on different occasions;
             1404          (vi) any damage to internal organs of the body;
             1405          (vii) any conduct toward a child which results in [severe emotional harm, severe]
             1406      serious developmental delay or retardation[,] or [severe] serious impairment of the child's
             1407      ability to function;
             1408          (viii) any injury which creates a permanent disfigurement or protracted loss or
             1409      impairment of the function of a bodily member, limb, or organ;
             1410          (ix) any conduct which causes a child to cease breathing, even if resuscitation is
             1411      successful following the conduct; or
             1412          (x) any conduct which results in starvation or failure to thrive or malnutrition that
             1413      jeopardizes the child's life.
             1414          (2) Any person who inflicts upon a child serious physical injury or mental cruelty or,
             1415      having the care or custody of such child, causes or permits another to inflict serious physical
             1416      injury or mental cruelty upon a child is guilty of an offense as follows:
             1417          (a) if done intentionally or knowingly, the offense is a felony of the second degree;
             1418          (b) if done recklessly, the offense is a felony of the third degree; or
             1419          (c) if done with criminal negligence, the offense is a class A misdemeanor.
             1420          (3) Any person who inflicts upon a child physical injury or, having the care or custody
             1421      of such child, causes or permits another to inflict physical injury upon a child is guilty of an
             1422      offense as follows:

             1423          (a) if done intentionally or knowingly, the offense is a class A misdemeanor;
             1424          (b) if done recklessly, the offense is a class B misdemeanor; or
             1425          (c) if done with criminal negligence, the offense is a class C misdemeanor.
             1426          (4) A parent or legal guardian who provides a child with treatment by spiritual means
             1427      alone through prayer, in lieu of medical or mental health treatment, in accordance with the
             1428      tenets and practices of an established church or religious denomination of which the parent or
             1429      legal guardian is a member or adherent shall not, for that reason alone, be [deemed] considered
             1430      to have committed an offense under this section.
             1431          (5) A parent or legal guardian who refuses traditional medical or mental health
             1432      treatment on behalf of a child in order for the child to receive nontraditional medical or mental
             1433      health treatment under the care of a medical, mental health, or other practitioner may not, for
             1434      that reason alone, be considered to have committed an offense under this section.
             1435          Section 26. Section 76-5-110 is amended to read:

             1459      the tenets and practices of an established church or religious denomination of which the parent

             1467          Section 27. Section 78-3a-102 is amended to read:
             1468           78-3a-102. Establishment of juvenile court -- Organization and status of court --
             1469      Purpose.
             1470          (1) There is established for the state a juvenile court.
             1471          (2) The juvenile court is a court of record. It shall have a seal, and its judges, clerks,
             1472      and referees have the power to administer oaths and affirmations.
             1473          (3) The juvenile court is of equal status with the district courts of the state.
             1474          (4) The juvenile court is established as a forum for the resolution of all matters
             1475      properly brought before it, consistent with applicable constitutional and statutory requirements
             1476      of due process.
             1477          (5) The purpose of the court under this chapter is to:
             1478          (a) promote public safety and individual accountability by the imposition of
             1479      appropriate sanctions on persons who have committed acts in violation of law;
             1480          (b) order appropriate measures to promote guidance and control, preferably in the
             1481      minor's own home, as an aid in the prevention of future unlawful conduct and the development
             1482      of responsible citizenship;
             1483          (c) where appropriate, order rehabilitation, reeducation, and treatment for persons who
             1484      have committed acts bringing them within the court's jurisdiction;

             1485          (d) adjudicate matters that relate to minors who are beyond parental or adult control
             1486      and to establish appropriate authority over these minors by means of placement and control
             1487      orders;
             1488          (e) adjudicate matters that relate to abused, neglected, and dependent minors and to
             1489      provide care and protection for these minors by placement, protection, and custody orders;
             1490          (f) remove a minor from parental custody only where the minor's health or safety [or
             1491      welfare], or the public safety, may not otherwise be adequately safeguarded; and
             1492          (g) consistent with the ends of justice, strive to act in the best interests of [the minor's]
             1493      minors in all cases and attempt to preserve and strengthen family ties where possible.

             1654          (E) sexual abuse.
             1655          (ii) "Abused child" does not include a child who has been the subject of:
             1656          (A) unintentional incidents resulting from ordinary human error, including
             1657      unintentional accidents and unintentional injuries, unless the injury, accident, or other incident
             1658      was caused intentionally, knowingly, recklessly, or with criminal negligence, as defined in
             1659      Section 76-2-103 ; and
             1660          (B) reasonable parental discipline or management with which the child may disagree,
             1661      including prohibiting the use of an automobile or other possession and the withholding of other
             1662      privileges, if the prohibiting or withholding does not constitute serious physical abuse, serious
             1663      neglect, sexual abuse or exploitation, or mental cruelty.
             1664          (b) "Adjudication" means a finding by the court, incorporated in a decree, that the facts
             1665      alleged in the petition have been proved.
             1666          (c) "Adult" means a person 18 years of age or over, except that persons 18 years or
             1667      over under the continuing jurisdiction of the juvenile court pursuant to Section 78-3a-121 shall
             1668      be referred to as minors.
             1669          (d) "Board" means the Board of Juvenile Court Judges.
             1670          (e) "Child placement agency" means:

             1671          (i) a private agency licensed to receive minors for placement or adoption under this
             1672      code; or
             1673          (ii) a private agency receiving minors for placement or adoption in another state, which
             1674      agency is licensed or approved where such license or approval is required by law.
             1675          (f) "Commit" means to transfer legal custody.
             1676          (g) "Court" means the juvenile court.
             1677          (h) "Dependent child" includes a minor who is homeless or without [proper] adequate
             1678      care through no fault of [his] the minor's parent, guardian, or custodian.
             1679          (i) "Deprivation of custody" means transfer of legal custody by the court from a parent
             1680      or the parents or a previous legal custodian to another person, agency, or institution.
             1681          (j) "Detention" means home detention and secure detention as defined in Section
             1682      62A-7-101 for the temporary care of minors who require secure custody in physically
             1683      restricting facilities:
             1684          (i) pending court disposition or transfer to another jurisdiction; or
             1685          (ii) while under the continuing jurisdiction of the court.
             1686          (k) "Division" means the Division of Child and Family Services.
             1687          (l) "Formal referral" means a written report from a peace officer or other person
             1688      informing the court that a minor is or appears to be within the court's jurisdiction and that a
             1689      petition may be filed.
             1690          (m) "Group rehabilitation therapy" means psychological and social counseling of one
             1691      or more persons in the group, depending upon the recommendation of the therapist.
             1692          (n) "Guardianship of the person" includes the authority to consent to:
             1693          (i) marriage[, to];
             1694          (ii) enlistment in the armed forces[, to];
             1695          (iii) major medical[,] or surgical[, or] treatment;
             1696          (iv) psychiatric or other mental health treatment[,]; and [to]
             1697          (v) legal custody, if legal custody is not vested in another person, agency, or institution.
             1698          (o) "Habitual truant" is a school-age minor who has received more than two truancy
             1699      citations within one school year from the school in which the minor is or should be enrolled
             1700      and eight absences without a legitimate or valid excuse or who, in defiance of efforts on the
             1701      part of school authorities as required under Section 53A-11-103 , refuses to regularly attend

             1702      school or any scheduled period of the school day.
             1703          (p) "Legal custody" means a relationship embodying the following rights and duties:
             1704          (i) the right to physical custody of the minor;
             1705          (ii) the right and duty to protect, train, and discipline the minor;
             1706          (iii) the duty to provide the minor with food, clothing, shelter, education, and ordinary
             1707      medical care;
             1708          (iv) the right to determine where and with whom the minor shall live; and
             1709          (v) the right, in an emergency, to authorize surgery or other extraordinary care.
             1710          (q) "Mental cruelty" has the same meaning as defined in Section 76-5-109 .
             1711          [(q)] (r) "Minor" means a person under the age of 18 years. It includes the term "child"
             1712      as used in other parts of this chapter.
             1713          [(r)] (s) "Natural parent" means a minor's biological or adoptive parent, and includes
             1714      the minor's noncustodial parent.
             1715          [(s)] (t) (i) "Neglected child" means a minor[: (A)] whose parent, guardian, or
             1716      custodian has demonstrated repeated failure to provide adequate food, shelter, clothing,
             1717      training, or physical safety to the minor.
             1718          (ii) "Neglected child" includes a minor whose parent, guardian, or custodian has:
             1719          (A) abandoned the minor, except as provided in Title 62A, Chapter 4a, Part 8, Safe
             1720      Relinquishment of a Newborn Child; and
             1721          (B) demonstrated a lack of adequate care for the minor.
             1722          [(B) whose parent, guardian, or custodian has subjected the minor to mistreatment or
             1723      abuse;]
             1724          [(C) who lacks proper parental care by reason of the fault or habits of the parent,
             1725      guardian, or custodian;]
             1726          [(D) whose parent, guardian, or custodian fails or refuses to provide proper or
             1727      necessary subsistence, education, or medical care, including surgery or psychiatric services
             1728      when required, or any other care necessary for health, safety, morals, or well-being; or]
             1729          [(E) who is at risk of being a neglected or abused child as defined in this chapter
             1730      because another minor in the same home is a neglected or abused child as defined in this
             1731      chapter.]
             1732          [(ii) The aspect of neglect related to education, described in Subsection (1)(s)(i)(D),

             1733      means that, after receiving notice that a minor has been frequently absent from school without
             1734      good cause, or that the minor has failed to cooperate with school authorities in a reasonable
             1735      manner, a parent or guardian fails to make a good faith effort to ensure that the minor receives
             1736      an appropriate education.]
             1737          (iii) [A] "Neglected child" does not include a minor whose parent [or], guardian, or
             1738      custodian:
             1739          (A) is legitimately practicing religious beliefs and who, for that reason, does not
             1740      provide specified medical or mental health treatment for [a] the minor[, is not guilty of
             1741      neglect.]; and
             1742          (B) who experiences unintentional incidents, or reasonable parental discipline or
             1743      management, described in Subsection (1)(a)(ii).
             1744          [(t)] (u) "Nonjudicial adjustment" means closure of the case by the assigned probation
             1745      officer without judicial determination upon the consent in writing of the minor, the parent,
             1746      legal guardian or custodian, and the assigned probation officer.
             1747          (v) "Physical abuse" has the same meaning as "physical injury," as defined in Section
             1748      76-5-109 .
             1749          [(u)] (w) "Probation" means a legal status created by court order following an
             1750      adjudication on the ground of a violation of law or under Section 78-3a-104 , whereby the
             1751      minor is permitted to remain in [his] the minor's home under prescribed conditions and under
             1752      supervision by the probation department or other agency designated by the court, subject to
             1753      return to the court for violation of any of the conditions prescribed.
             1754          [(v)] (x) "Protective supervision" means a legal status created by court order following
             1755      an adjudication on the ground of abuse, neglect, or dependency, whereby the minor is permitted
             1756      to remain in [his] the minor's home, and supervision and assistance to correct the abuse,
             1757      neglect, or dependency is provided by the probation department or other agency designated by
             1758      the court.
             1759          [(w)] (y) "Residual parental rights and duties" means those rights and duties remaining
             1760      with the parent after legal custody or guardianship, or both, have been vested in another person
             1761      or agency, including the responsibility for support, the right to consent to adoption, the right to
             1762      determine the child's religious affiliation, and the right to reasonable parent-time unless
             1763      restricted by the court. If no guardian has been appointed, "residual parental rights and duties"

             1764      also include the right to consent to marriage, to enlistment, and to major medical, surgical, or
             1765      psychiatric or other mental health treatment.
             1766          [(x)] (z) "Secure facility" means any facility operated by or under contract with the
             1767      Division of Juvenile Justice Services, that provides 24-hour supervision and confinement for
             1768      youth offenders committed to the division for custody and rehabilitation.
             1769          (aa) "Serious neglect" has the same meaning as defined in Section 62A-4a-101 .
             1770          (bb) "Serious physical abuse" has the same meaning as "serious physical injury," as
             1771      defined in Section 76-5-109 .
             1772          [(y)] (cc) "Shelter" means the temporary care of minors in physically unrestricted
             1773      facilities pending court disposition or transfer to another jurisdiction.
             1774          [(z)] (dd) "State supervision" means a disposition which provides a more intensive
             1775      level of intervention than standard probation but is less intensive or restrictive than a
             1776      community placement with the Division of Juvenile Justice Services.
             1777          [(aa)] (ee) "Substantiated" has the same meaning as defined in Section 62A-4a-101 .
             1778          [(bb)] (ff) "Supported" has the same meaning as defined in Section 62A-4a-101 .
             1779          [(cc)] (gg) "Termination of parental rights" means the permanent elimination of all
             1780      parental rights and duties, including residual parental rights and duties, by court order.
             1781          [(dd)] (hh) "Therapist" means a person employed by a state division or agency for the
             1782      purpose of conducting psychological treatment and counseling of a minor in its custody, or any
             1783      other person licensed or approved by the state for the purpose of conducting psychological
             1784      treatment and counseling.
             1785          [(ee)] (ii) "Unsubstantiated" has the same meaning as defined in Section 62A-4a-101 .
             1786          [(ff)] (jj) "Without merit" has the same meaning as defined in Section 62A-4a-101 .
             1787          (2) As used in Part 3, Abuse, Neglect, and Dependency Proceedings, with regard to the
             1788      division [of Child and Family Services]:
             1789          (a) "Custody" means the custody of a minor in the division [of Child and Family
             1790      Services] as of the date of disposition.

             1792      Family Services] from the time the minor is removed from home until the shelter hearing, or

             1796          Section 30. Section 78-3a-106 is amended to read:

             1837          (3) The parent or guardian to be notified must be the minor's primary caregiver, or the

             1839          Section 31. Section 78-3a-110 is amended to read:
             1840           78-3a-110. Summons -- Service and process -- Issuance and contents -- Notice to
             1841      absent parent or guardian -- Emergency medical or surgical treatment -- Compulsory
             1842      process for attendance of witnesses when authorized.
             1843          (1) After a petition is filed the court shall promptly issue a summons, unless the judge
             1844      directs that a further investigation is needed. No summons is required as to any person who
             1845      appears voluntarily or who files a written waiver of service with the clerk of the court at or
             1846      prior to the hearing.
             1847          (2) The summons shall contain:
             1848          (a) the name of the court;
             1849          (b) the title of the proceedings; and
             1850          (c) except for a published summons, a brief statement of the substance of the
             1851      allegations in the petition.
             1852          (3) A published summons shall state:
             1853          (a) that a proceeding concerning the minor is pending in the court; and
             1854          (b) an adjudication will be made.
             1855          (4) The summons shall require the person or persons who have physical custody of the
             1856      minor to appear personally and bring the minor before the court at a time and place stated. If

             1857      the person or persons summoned are not the parent, parents, or guardian of the minor, the
             1858      summons shall also be issued to the parent, parents, or guardian, as the case may be, notifying
             1859      them of the pendency of the case and of the time and place set for the hearing.
             1860          (5) Summons may be issued requiring the appearance of any other person whose
             1861      presence the court finds necessary.
             1862          (6) If it appears to the court that the [welfare] health or safety of the minor or the
             1863      welfare of the public requires that the minor be taken into custody, the court may by
             1864      endorsement upon the summons direct that the person serving the summons take the minor into
             1865      custody at once.
             1866          (7) [Upon] Subject to the provisions of Subsection 78-3a-118 (2)(n) and upon the sworn
             1867      testimony of one or more reputable physicians, the court may order emergency medical or
             1868      surgical treatment that is immediately necessary for a minor concerning whom a petition has
             1869      been filed pending the service of summons upon [his] the minor's parents, guardian, or
             1870      custodian.
             1871          (8) (a) A parent or guardian is entitled to the issuance of compulsory process for the
             1872      attendance of witnesses on [his] the parent's or guardian's own behalf or on behalf of the minor.
             1873          (b) A guardian ad litem or a probation officer is entitled to compulsory process for the
             1874      attendance of witnesses on behalf of the minor.
             1875          (9) Service of summons and process and proof of service shall be made in the manner
             1876      provided in the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
             1877          (10) Service of summons or process shall be made by the sheriff of the county where
             1878      the service is to be made, or by [his] the sheriff's deputy[; but], except that upon request of the
             1879      court, service shall be made by any other peace officer, or by another suitable person selected
             1880      by the court.
             1881          (11) (a) Service of summons in the state shall be made personally[,] by delivering a
             1882      copy to the person summoned[; provided, however, that].
             1883          (b) If the parents of a minor are living together at their usual place of abode [may],
             1884      both may be served by personal delivery to either parent of copies of the summons, one copy
             1885      for each parent.
             1886          (12) If [the] a judge makes a written finding that [he] the judge has reason to believe
             1887      that personal service of the summons will be unsuccessful, or will not accomplish notification

             1888      within a reasonable time after issuance of the summons, [he] the judge may order service by
             1889      registered mail, with a return receipt to be signed by the addressee only, to be addressed to the
             1890      last-known address of the person to be served in the state. Service shall be complete upon
             1891      return to the court of the signed receipt.
             1892          (13) (a) If the parents, parent, or guardian required to be summoned under Subsection
             1893      (4) cannot be found within the state, the fact of their minor's presence within the state shall
             1894      confer jurisdiction on the court in proceedings in minor's cases under this chapter as to any
             1895      absent parent or guardian, provided that due notice has been given [in the following manner:]
             1896      as provided in Subsection (13)(b).
             1897          [(a)] (b) (i) If the address of the parent or guardian is known, due notice is given by
             1898      sending him a copy of the summons by registered mail with a return receipt to be signed by the
             1899      addressee only, or by personal service outside the state, as provided in the Utah Rules of Civil
             1900      Procedure. Service by registered mail shall be complete upon return to the court of the signed
             1901      receipt.
             1902          [(b)] (ii) If the address or whereabouts of the parent or guardian outside the state
             1903      cannot after diligent inquiry be ascertained, due notice is given by publishing a summons in a
             1904      newspaper having general circulation in the county in which the proceeding is pending. The
             1905      summons shall be published once a week for four successive weeks. Service shall be complete

             1907          (c) Service of summons as provided in this Subsection (13) shall vest the court with

             1911      before the time set in the summons for the appearance of the person served, shall be sufficient
             1912      to confer jurisdiction.
             1913          (b) In the case of service outside the state, service completed not less than five days
             1914      before the time set in the summons for appearance of the person served, shall be sufficient to

             1916          (15) Computation of periods of time under this chapter shall be made in accordance

             1918          Section 32. Section 78-3a-112 is amended to read:

             1919           78-3a-112. Appearances -- Parents to appear with minor -- Failure to appear --
             1920      Contempt -- Warrant of arrest, when authorized -- Parent's employer to grant time off --
             1921      Appointment of guardian ad litem.
             1922          (1) Any person required to appear who, without reasonable cause, fails to appear may
             1923      be proceeded against for contempt of court, and the court may cause a bench warrant to issue to
             1924      produce the person in court.
             1925          (2) In all cases when a minor is required to appear in court, the parents, guardian, or
             1926      other person with legal custody of the minor shall appear with the minor unless excused by the
             1927      judge.
             1928          (a) An employee may request permission to leave the workplace for the purpose of
             1929      attending court if the employee has been notified by the juvenile court that [his] the minor of
             1930      the employee is required to appear before the court.
             1931          (b) An employer must grant permission to leave the workplace with or without pay if
             1932      the employee has requested permission at least seven days in advance or within 24 hours of the
             1933      employee receiving notice of the hearing.
             1934          (3) If a parent or other person who signed a written promise to appear and bring the
             1935      minor to court under Section 78-3a-113 or 78-3a-114 , fails to appear and bring the minor to
             1936      court on the date set in the promise, or, if the date was to be set, after notification by the court,
             1937      a warrant may be issued for the apprehension of that person [or], the minor, or both.
             1938          (4) Willful failure to perform the promise is a misdemeanor if, at the time of the
             1939      execution of the promise, the promisor is given a copy of the promise which clearly states that
             1940      failure to appear and have the minor appear as promised is a misdemeanor. The juvenile court
             1941      shall have jurisdiction to proceed against the promisor in adult proceedings pursuant to Part 8,
             1942      Adult Offenses.
             1943          (5) The court shall endeavor, through use of the warrant of arrest if necessary, as
             1944      provided in Subsection (6), or by other means, to ensure the presence at all hearings of one or
             1945      both parents or of the guardian of the minor. If neither a parent nor guardian is present at the
             1946      court proceedings, the court may appoint a guardian ad litem to protect the interest of the
             1947      minor. A guardian ad litem may also be appointed whenever necessary for the welfare of the
             1948      minor, whether or not a parent or guardian is present.
             1949          (6) A warrant may be issued for the parent, the guardian, the custodian, or the minor if:

             1950          (a) a summons is issued but cannot be served;
             1951          (b) it [is made to appear] appears to the court that the person to be served will not obey
             1952      the summons;
             1953          (c) serving the summons will be ineffectual; or
             1954          (d) the [welfare] health or safety of the minor requires that [he] the minor be brought
             1955      immediately into the custody of the court.
             1956          Section 33. Section 78-3a-113 (Superseded 07/01/04) is amended to read:
             1957           78-3a-113 (Superseded 07/01/04). Minor taken into custody by peace officer,
             1958      private citizen, or probation officer -- Grounds -- Notice requirements -- Release or
             1959      detention -- Grounds for peace officer to take adult into custody.
             1960          (1) A [minor may be taken into custody by a] peace officer may take a minor into
             1961      custody without order of the court if:
             1962          (a) in the presence of the officer the minor has violated a state law, federal law, local
             1963      law, or municipal ordinance;
             1964          (b) there are reasonable grounds to believe the minor has committed an act which if
             1965      committed by an adult would be a felony;
             1966          (c) the minor is seriously endangered in [his] the minor's surroundings or if the minor
             1967      seriously endangers others, and immediate removal appears to be necessary for [his] the
             1968      minor's protection or the protection of others;
             1969          (d) there are reasonable grounds to believe the minor has run away or escaped from
             1970      [his] the minor's parents, guardian, or custodian; or
             1971          (e) there is reason to believe the minor is subject to the state's compulsory education
             1972      law and that the minor is absent from school without legitimate or valid excuse, subject to
             1973      Section 53A-11-105 .
             1974          (2) (a) A private citizen or a probation officer may take a minor into custody if under
             1975      the circumstances [he] the person could make a citizen's arrest if the minor [was] were an adult.
             1976          (b) A probation officer may also take a minor into custody under Subsection (1) or if
             1977      the minor has violated the conditions of probation, if the minor is under the continuing
             1978      jurisdiction of the juvenile court or in emergency situations in which a peace officer is not
             1979      immediately available.
             1980          (3) (a) If an officer or other person takes a minor into temporary custody, [he] the

             1981      officer or other person shall without unnecessary delay notify the parents, guardian, or
             1982      custodian. The minor shall then be released to the care of [his] the minor's parent or other
             1983      responsible adult, unless [his] the minor's immediate [welfare] health or safety or the protection
             1984      of the community requires [his] the minor's detention.
             1985          (b) Before the minor is released, the parent or other person to whom the minor is
             1986      released shall be required to sign a written promise on forms supplied by the court to bring the
             1987      minor to the court at a time set or to be set by the court.
             1988          (4) (a) A minor may not be held in temporary custody by law enforcement any longer
             1989      than is reasonably necessary to obtain [his] the minor's name, age, residence, and other
             1990      necessary information and to contact [his] the minor's parents, guardian, or custodian.
             1991          (b) If the minor is not released under Subsection (3), [he] the minor shall be taken to a
             1992      place of detention or shelter without unnecessary delay.
             1993          (5) (a) The person who takes a minor to a detention or shelter facility shall promptly
             1994      file with the detention or shelter facility a written report on a form provided by the division
             1995      stating the details of the presently alleged offense, the facts which bring the minor within the
             1996      jurisdiction of the juvenile court, and the reason the minor was not released by law
             1997      enforcement.
             1998          (b) (i) The designated youth corrections facility staff person shall immediately review
             1999      the form and determine, based on the guidelines for detention admissions established by the
             2000      Division of Youth Corrections under Sections 62A-7-104 and 62A-7-205 , whether:
             2001          (A) to admit the minor to secure detention[,];
             2002          (B) to admit the minor to home detention[,];
             2003          (C) to place the minor in a placement other than detention[,]; or
             2004          (D) to return the minor home:
             2005          (I) upon written promise to bring the minor to the court at a time set[,]; or
             2006          (II) without restriction.
             2007          (ii) If the designated youth corrections facility staff person determines to admit the
             2008      minor to home detention, that staff person shall notify the juvenile court of that determination.
             2009      The court shall order that notice be provided to the designated persons in the local law
             2010      enforcement agency and the school or transferee school, if applicable, which the minor attends
             2011      of the home detention. The designated persons may receive the information for purposes of the

             2012      minor's supervision and student safety.
             2013          (iii) Any employee of the local law enforcement agency and the school which the
             2014      minor attends who discloses the notification of home detention is not:
             2015          (A) civilly liable except when disclosure constitutes fraud or malice as provided in
             2016      Section 63-30-4 ; and
             2017          (B) civilly or criminally liable except when disclosure constitutes a knowing violation
             2018      of Section 63-2-801 .
             2019          (c) A minor may not be admitted to detention unless the minor is detainable based on
             2020      the guidelines or the minor has been brought to detention pursuant to a judicial order or
             2021      division warrant pursuant to Subsection 62A-7-112 (8).
             2022          (d) If a minor taken to detention does not qualify for admission under the guidelines
             2023      established by the division under Sections 62A-7-104 and 62A-7-205 , detention staff shall
             2024      arrange appropriate placement.
             2025          (e) If a minor is taken into custody and admitted to a secure detention or shelter
             2026      facility, facility staff shall immediately notify the minor's parents, guardian, or custodian and
             2027      shall promptly notify the court of the placement.
             2028          (f) If the minor is admitted to a secure detention or shelter facility outside the county of
             2029      [his] the minor's residence and it is determined in the hearing held under Subsection
             2030      78-3a-114 (3) that detention shall continue, the judge or commissioner shall direct the sheriff of
             2031      the county of the minor's residence to transport the minor to a detention or shelter facility as
             2032      provided in this section.
             2033          (6) A person may be taken into custody by a peace officer without a court order if:
             2034          (a) the person is in apparent violation of a protective order; or [if]
             2035          (b) there is reason to believe that a minor is being abused by the person and any of the
             2036      situations outlined in Section 77-7-2 exist.

             2290          (n) (i) [The] Except as provided in Subsection (2)(n)(ii), the court may order that the

             2291      minor be examined or treated by a physician, surgeon, psychiatrist, or psychologist or that [he]

             2296      provision of law unless:

             2298      significant risk of producing serious side effects, including:

             2304          (VI) thought disorders;
             2305          (VII) tardive dyskenisia;
             2306          (VIII) brain function impairment; or
             2307          (IX) emotional harm resulting from the compulsory nature of the examination,
             2308      treatment, or special care; and
             2309          (B) (I) at least one of the minor's parents or guardian consents to the examination,
             2310      treatment, or special care; or
             2311          (II) evidence demonstrates beyond a reasonable doubt that the examination, treatment,
             2312      or special care provided by the parents or legal guardian, or the lack thereof, will result in an
             2313      immediate serious threat to the life or essential physiological functions of the minor.

             2315      necessary in the interest of the minor, and may appoint as guardian a public or private

             2319      minor. [When practicable, the] The court [may] shall take into consideration the religious
             2320      preferences of the minor and of the minor's parents.

             2323      any other person who has been made a party to the proceedings. Conditions may include:

             2345          (u) The court may combine the dispositions listed in this section if they are compatible.

             2961      failure of a party to comply with notice provisions, or any other procedural requirement of this
             2962      chapter or Title 62A, Chapter 4a, Child and Family Services.
             2963          Section 42. Section 78-3a-311 is amended to read:
             2964           78-3a-311. Dispositional hearing -- Reunification services -- Exceptions.
             2965          (1) The court may make any of the dispositions described in Section 78-3a-118 , place
             2966      the child in the custody or guardianship of any individual or public or private entity or agency,
             2967      or order protective supervision, family preservation, medical or mental health treatment, or
             2968      other services.
             2969          (2) (a) (i) Whenever the court orders continued removal at the dispositional hearing,
             2970      and that the minor remain in the custody of the division [of Child and Family Services], it shall
             2971      first establish a primary permanency goal for the minor and determine whether, in view of the
             2972      primary permanency goal, reunification services are appropriate for the child and the child's

             2973      family, pursuant to Subsection (3).
             2974          (ii) When the court determines that reunification services are appropriate for the child
             2975      and the child's family, the court shall provide for reasonable parent-time with the parent or
             2976      parents from whose custody the child was removed, unless:
             2977          (A) parent-time [is not in the best interest] would threaten the physical safety or life of
             2978      the child[.];
             2979          (B) the child suffered at the hands of the parent:
             2980          (I) sexual abuse or sexual exploitation; or
             2981          (II) serious physical abuse or mental cruelty, and parent-time would cause the child
             2982      serious emotional anguish.
             2983          (iii) In cases where obvious sexual abuse, abandonment, or serious physical abuse or
             2984      serious neglect are involved, neither the division nor the court has any duty to make
             2985      "reasonable efforts" or to, in any other way, attempt to provide reunification services, or to
             2986      attempt to rehabilitate the offending parent or parents. In all cases, the child's health[,] and
             2987      safety[, and welfare] shall be the court's [paramount] primary concern in determining whether
             2988      reasonable efforts to reunify should be made.
             2989          (b) (i) In addition to the primary permanency goal, the court shall establish a
             2990      concurrent permanency goal. The concurrent permanency goal shall include a representative
             2991      list of the conditions under which the primary permanency goal will be abandoned in favor of
             2992      the concurrent permanency goal and an explanation of the effect of abandoning or modifying
             2993      the primary permanency goal.
             2994          (ii) A permanency hearing shall be conducted in accordance with Subsection
             2995      78-3a-312 (1)(b) within 30 days if something other than reunification is initially established as a
             2996      child's primary permanency goal.
             2997          (iii) (A) The court may amend a child's primary permanency goal before the
             2998      establishment of a final permanency plan under Section 78-3a-312 . The court is not limited to
             2999      the terms of the concurrent permanency goal in the event that the primary permanency goal is
             3000      abandoned.
             3001          (B) If, at anytime, the court determines that reunification is no longer a child's primary
             3002      permanency goal, the court shall conduct a permanency hearing in accordance with Section
             3003      78-3a-312 within the earlier of 30 days of the court's determination or 12 months from the

             3004      original removal of the child.
             3005          (c) (i) If the court determines that reunification services are appropriate, it shall order
             3006      that the division make reasonable efforts to provide services to the child and the child's parent
             3007      for the purpose of facilitating reunification of the family, for a specified period of time. In
             3008      providing those services, the child's health[,] and safety[, and welfare] shall be the division's
             3009      [paramount] primary concern, and the court shall so order.
             3010          (ii) The court shall determine whether the services offered or provided by the division
             3011      under the treatment plan constitute "reasonable efforts" on the part of the division. The court
             3012      shall also determine and define the responsibilities of the parent under the treatment plan.
             3013      Those duties and responsibilities shall be identified on the record, for the purpose of assisting
             3014      in any future determination regarding the provision of reasonable efforts, in accordance with
             3015      state and federal law.
             3016          (iii) The time period for reunification services may not exceed 12 months from the date
             3017      that the child was initially removed from the child's home. Nothing in this section may be
             3018      construed to entitle any parent to an entire 12 months of reunification services.
             3019          (iv) If reunification services have been ordered, the court may terminate those services
             3020      at any time.
             3021          (v) If, at any time, continuation of reasonable efforts to reunify a child is determined to
             3022      be inconsistent with the final permanency plan for the child established pursuant to Subsection
             3023      78-3a-312 , then measures shall be taken, in a timely manner, to place the child in accordance
             3024      with the permanency plan, and to complete whatever steps are necessary to finalize the
             3025      permanent placement of the child.
             3026          (d) Any physical custody of the minor by the parent or a relative during the period
             3027      described in Subsection (2)(c) does not interrupt the running of the period.
             3028          (e) (i) If reunification services have been ordered, a permanency hearing shall be
             3029      conducted by the court in accordance with Section 78-3a-312 at the expiration of the time
             3030      period for reunification services. The permanency hearing shall be held no later than 12
             3031      months after the original removal of the child.
             3032          (ii) If reunification services have not been ordered, a permanency hearing shall be
             3033      conducted within 30 days, in accordance with Section 78-3a-312 .
             3034          (f) With regard to a child who is 36 months of age or younger at the time the child is

             3035      initially removed from the home, the court shall:
             3036          (i) hold a permanency hearing eight months after the date of the initial removal,
             3037      pursuant to Section 78-3a-312 ; and
             3038          (ii) order the discontinuance of those services after eight months from the initial
             3039      removal of the child from the home if the parent or parents have not made substantial efforts to
             3040      comply with the treatment plan.
             3041          (g) With regard to a child in the custody of the division whose parent or parents have
             3042      been ordered to receive reunification services but who have abandoned that child for a period
             3043      of six months since the date that reunification services were ordered, the court shall terminate
             3044      reunification services, and the division shall petition the court for termination of parental
             3045      rights.
             3046          (3) (a) Because of the state's interest in and responsibility to protect and provide
             3047      permanency for children who are abused, neglected, or dependent, the Legislature finds that a
             3048      parent's interest in receiving reunification services is limited. The court may determine that
             3049      efforts to reunify a child with the child's family are not reasonable or appropriate, based on the
             3050      individual circumstances, and that reunification services should not be provided. In
             3051      determining "reasonable efforts" to be made with respect to a child, and in making "reasonable
             3052      efforts," the child's health[,] and safety[, and welfare] shall be the [paramount] primary
             3053      concern.
             3054          (b) There is a presumption that reunification services should not be provided to a
             3055      parent if the court finds[, by clear and convincing] evidence that establishes beyond a
             3056      reasonable doubt, that any of the following circumstances exist:
             3057          (i) the whereabouts of the parents are unknown, based upon a verified affidavit
             3058      indicating that a reasonably diligent search has failed to locate the parent;
             3059          (ii) the parent is suffering from a mental [illness] incapacity of such magnitude that it
             3060      renders [him] the parent incapable of utilizing reunification services; that finding shall be based
             3061      on competent evidence from at least two mental health or medical professionals, who are not
             3062      associates, establishing that, even with the provision of services, the parent [is unlikely to be
             3063      capable] will be incapable of adequately caring for the child within 12 months;
             3064          (iii) the minor has been previously adjudicated as an abused child due to physical or
             3065      sexual abuse, that following the adjudication the [child] minor was removed from the custody

             3066      of [his] the minor's parent, was subsequently returned to the custody of that parent, and the
             3067      minor is being removed due to additional physical or sexual abuse;
             3068          (iv) the parent has caused the death of another child through abuse or neglect or has
             3069      committed, aided, abetted, attempted, conspired, or solicited to commit murder or
             3070      manslaughter of a child or child abuse homicide;
             3071          (v) the minor has suffered [severe] serious abuse by the parent or by any person known
             3072      by the parent, if the parent knew or reasonably should have known that the person was abusing
             3073      the minor;
             3074          (vi) the minor has been adjudicated an abused child as a result of [severe] serious abuse
             3075      by the parent, and the court finds that it would not benefit the child to pursue reunification
             3076      services with the offending parent;
             3077          (vii) the parent's rights have been terminated with regard to any other child;
             3078          (viii) the child has been removed from [his] the child's home on at least two previous
             3079      occasions and reunification services were offered or provided to the family at those times; or
             3080          (ix) the parent has abandoned the child for a period of six months or longer[; or].
             3081          [(x) any other circumstance that the court determines should preclude reunification
             3082      efforts or services.]
             3083          (4) (a) Failure of the parent to [respond to previous services or] comply with [any]
             3084      essential components of a previous treatment plan, the fact that the child was abused while the
             3085      parent was under the influence of drugs or alcohol, a past history of violent behavior directed at
             3086      the child, whether a parent continues to live with an individual who seriously abused the child,
             3087      or any patterns of the parent's behavior that have exposed the child to repeated serious abuse[,
             3088      or testimony by a competent professional that the parent's behavior is unlikely to be
             3089      successful,] shall be considered in determining whether reunification services are appropriate.
             3090          (b) The court shall also consider whether the parent has expressed an interest in
             3091      reunification with the child, in determining whether reunification services are appropriate.
             3092          (5) If reunification services are not ordered pursuant to Subsection (3)(a), and the
             3093      whereabouts of a parent become known within six months of the out-of-home placement of the
             3094      minor, the court may order the division to provide reunification services. The time limits
             3095      described in Subsection (2), however, are not tolled by the parent's absence.
             3096          (6) (a) If a parent is incarcerated or institutionalized, the court shall order reasonable

             3097      services unless it determines that those services would be seriously detrimental to the health or
             3098      safety of the minor. In determining detriment, the court shall consider:
             3099          (i) the age of the child[,];
             3100          (ii) the degree of parent-child bonding[,];
             3101          (iii) the length of the sentence[,];
             3102          (iv) the nature of the treatment[,];
             3103          (v) the nature of the crime or [illness,] mental incapacity;
             3104          (vi) the degree of detriment to the [child] child's health and safety if services are not
             3105      offered [and,];
             3106          (vii) for minors ten years of age or older, the minor's attitude toward the
             3107      implementation of family reunification services[, and], which shall be given particular
             3108      consideration and weight; and
             3109          (viii) any other appropriate factors.
             3110          (b) (i) Reunification services for an incarcerated parent are subject to the 12-month

             3112          (ii) Reunification services for an institutionalized parent are subject to the 12-month

             3280      months;]
             3281          [(c) failed to have shown the normal interest of a natural parent, without just cause; o]r
             3282          [(d) have abandoned an infant, as described in Section 78-3a-313.5 .]

             3283          [(2) In determining whether a parent or parents are unfit or have neglected a child the
             3284      court shall consider, but is not limited to, the following circumstances, conduct, or conditions:]
             3285          [(a) emotional illness, mental illness, or mental deficiency of the parent that renders
             3286      him unable to care for the immediate and continuing physical or emotional needs of the child
             3287      for extended periods of time;]
             3288          (1) When considering evidence for grounds for terminating parental rights, the court
             3289      shall consider the following circumstances, conduct, or conditions:
             3290          [(b)] (a) conduct toward a child of a physically, emotionally, or sexually cruel or
             3291      abusive nature;
             3292          [(c)] (b) habitual or excessive use of intoxicating liquors, controlled substances, or
             3293      dangerous drugs that render the parent unable to care for the child;
             3294          [(d)] (c) repeated or continuous failure to provide the child with adequate food,
             3295      clothing, shelter, education, or other care necessary for [his] the child's physical[,] and mental[,
             3296      and emotional] health and development by a parent or parents who are capable of providing
             3297      that care[. However, a parent who, legitimately practicing his religious beliefs, does not
             3298      provide specified medical treatment for a child is not for that reason alone a negligent or unfit
             3299      parent];
             3300          [(e)] (d) with regard to a child who is in the custody of the division, [if] whether the
             3301      parent is incarcerated as a result of conviction of a felony, and the sentence is of such length
             3302      that the child will be deprived of a normal home for more than one year; [or]
             3303          [(f)] (e) a history of violent behavior[.];
             3304          [(3) If a child has been placed in the custody of the division and the parent or parents
             3305      fail to comply substantially with the terms and conditions of a plan within six months after the
             3306      date on which the child was placed or the plan was commenced, whichever occurs later, that
             3307      failure to comply is evidence of failure of parental adjustment.]
             3308          [(4) The following circumstances constitute prima facie evidence of unfitness:]
             3309          [(a)] (f) sexual abuse, injury, or death of a sibling of the child, or of any child, due to
             3310      known or substantiated abuse or neglect by the parent or parents;
             3311          [(b)] (g) conviction of a crime, if the facts surrounding the crime are of such a nature as
             3312      to indicate the unfitness of the parent to provide adequate care to the extent necessary for the
             3313      child's physical, mental, or emotional health and development;

             3314          [(c)] (h) a single incident of life-threatening or gravely disabling injury to or
             3315      disfigurement of the child; [or] and
             3316          [(d)] (i) the parent has committed, aided, abetted, attempted, conspired, or solicited to
             3317      commit murder or manslaughter of a child or child abuse homicide.
             3318          (2) For purposes of Subsection (1)(c), a parent who, legitimately practicing the parent's
             3319      religious beliefs, does not provide specified medical treatment for a child is not for that reason
             3320      alone a negligent or unfit parent.
             3321          Section 49. Section 78-3a-414 is amended to read:
             3322           78-3a-414. Voluntary relinquishment -- Irrevocable.
             3323          (1) Voluntary relinquishment or consent for termination of parental rights shall be
             3324      signed or confirmed under oath either:
             3325          (a) before a judge of any court that has jurisdiction over proceedings for termination of
             3326      parental rights in this state or any other state, or a public officer appointed by that court for the
             3327      purpose of taking consents or relinquishments; or
             3328          (b) except as provided in Subsection (2), any person authorized to take consents or
             3329      relinquishments under Subsections 78-30-4.18 (1) and (2).
             3330          (2) Only the juvenile court is authorized to take consents or relinquishments from a
             3331      parent who has any child who is in the custody of a state agency or who has a child who is
             3332      otherwise under the jurisdiction of the juvenile court.
             3333          (3) The court, appointed officer, or other authorized person shall certify to the best of
             3334      that person's information and belief that the person executing the consent or relinquishment has
             3335      read and understands the consent or relinquishment and has signed it freely and voluntarily.
             3336          (4) A voluntary relinquishment or consent for termination of parental rights is effective
             3337      when it is signed and may not be revoked.
             3338          (5) The requirements and processes described in Sections 78-3a-402 through 78-3a-410
             3339      do not apply to a voluntary relinquishment or consent for termination of parental rights. The
             3340      court need only find that the relinquishment or termination is in the child's best interest.
             3341          (6) There is a presumption that voluntary relinquishment or consent for termination of
             3342      parental rights is not in the child's best interest where it appears to the court that the primary
             3343      purpose is to avoid a financial support obligation. The presumption may be rebutted, however,
             3344      if the court finds the relinquishment or consent to termination of parental rights will facilitate

             3345      the establishment of stability and permanency for the child.
             3346          (7) Upon granting a voluntary relinquishment the court may make orders relating to the
             3347      child's care, health, and [welfare] safety that the court considers to be in the child's best interest.
             3348          Section 50. Section 78-3g-101 is amended to read:
             3349           78-3g-101. Definitions.
             3350          As used in this chapter:
             3351          (1) "Board" means a foster care citizen review board created in accordance with
             3352      Section 78-3g-103 .
             3353          (2) "Committee" means the Foster Care Citizen Review Board Steering Committee
             3354      created in accordance with Section 78-3g-102 .
             3355          (3) "Division" means the Division of Child and Family Services within the Department
             3356      of Human Services.
             3357          (4) "Plan" means [the same as that term is defined in Subsection 78-3a-403 (3)] a
             3358      treatment plan required under Section 62A-4a-205 or a permanency plan.
             3359          Section 51. Repealer.
             3360          This bill repeals:
             3361          Section 62A-4a-202.7, Pilot program for differentiated responses to child abuse
             3362      and neglect reports.
             3363          Section 78-3a-403, Definitions.
             3364          Section 52. Effective date.
             3365          This bill takes effect on May 3, 2004, except that the amendments to Sections
             3366      62A-4a-202.1 (Effective 07/01/04), 78-3a-103 (Effective 07/01/04), 78-3a-113 (Effective
             3367      07/01/04), 78-3a-118 (Effective 07/01/04), and 78-3a-301 (Effective 07/01/04) take effect on
             3368      July 1, 2004.
